question: In 2019, a Florida man was arrested for throwing a ____ at a Wendy's employee.
A Florida man called 911 after a restaurant put ____ on his hamburger.
A Florida man was caught riding a ____ down the highway during rush hour.
A Florida man broke into a home and fell asleep on the couch while wearing ____.
A Florida man tried to pay for his McDonald's order with a bag of ____.
The world record for most ____ eaten in one minute is 72.
The longest ____ ever recorded lasted 68 days.
The world record for balancing ____ on the chin is 17 minutes.
A man in India holds the record for having the longest ____ at over 6 meters.
The record for most people inside a ____ at once is 28.
In Switzerland, it is illegal to own just one ____.
decoys: tying your giraffe to a lamp post

question: In Alabama, it is illegal to wear a ____ that could frighten a child.
decoys: carrying an ice cream cone in your pocket

question: In France, it is illegal to name a pig ____.
decoys: carrying an ice cream cone in your pocket

question: In Thailand, it is illegal to step on ____.
decoys: tying your giraffe to a lamp post
carrying an ice cream cone in your pocket

question: In Victoria, Australia, only licensed ____ are allowed to change a light bulb.
decoys: carrying an ice cream cone in your pocket

question: The most expensive pizza in the world costs $12,000 and is topped with ____.
Ketchup was originally sold as a ____ in the 1830s.
Honey never ____. Edible honey has been found in 3,000-year-old Egyptian tombs.
The original flavor of Froot Loops is actually ____ regardless of color.
Ranch dressing is dyed with ____ to make it look whiter.
Octopuses have ____ hearts.
A teaspoon of a neutron star would weigh about ____ pounds.
Bananas are slightly ____ due to their potassium content.
The smell of freshly cut grass is actually a plant ____ signal.
Hot water freezes ____ than cold water, a phenomenon called the Mpemba effect.
Cleopatra lived closer in time to the ____ than to the building of the Great Pyramid.
In ancient Rome, ____ was used as mouthwash.
Napoleon was once attacked by a horde of ____.
The Great Emu War of 1932 was fought in ____ and the emus won.
Vikings used to give ____ to kittens as wedding gifts.
Before becoming famous, Danny DeVito worked as a ____.
Keanu Reeves once gave ____ from his Matrix salary to the special effects team.
Christopher Walken used to work as a ____ at a circus.
Steve Buscemi volunteered as a ____ in New York City after 9/11.
Dolph Lundgren has a master's degree in ____.
In professional baseball, the average lifespan of a ball is ____ pitches.
Golf balls originally had ____ surfaces before dimples were discovered.
The Olympic gold medal is actually made mostly of ____.
In cricket, a score of zero is called a ____.
Tug of war was an Olympic sport until ____.
A group of flamingos is called a ____.
Cows have best friends and get ____ when separated.
A shrimp's heart is located in its ____.
Sea otters hold ____ while they sleep so they don't drift apart.
Dolphins sleep with one ____ open.
The first computer bug was an actual ____ found in a computer.
The average smartphone has more computing power than the computers used for the ____.
The first YouTube video ever uploaded was about a visit to the ____.
The @ symbol was almost replaced by ____ for email addresses.
Amazon's original name was ____.
A Florida man was arrested for practicing ____ without a license on an alligator.
In Singapore, it is illegal to sell ____.
decoys: tying your giraffe to a lamp post

question: Ancient Egyptians used ____ as pillows.
Wombat poop is shaped like a ____.
There are more ____ in your body than human cells.
During the Civil War, the Union Army used hot air balloons for ____.
The Liberty Bell cracked while ringing for the funeral of ____.
Before the bald eagle was chosen, Benjamin Franklin wanted America's national bird to be the ____.
During Prohibition, the U.S. government deliberately poisoned ____ to discourage drinking.
The shortest war in U.S. history lasted only ____ against Grenada in 1983.
Paul Revere never actually shouted "The British are coming!" — he reportedly said "The ____ are coming!"
In 1867, the U.S. purchased Alaska from Russia for ____ per acre.
The original Pledge of Allegiance was written in 1892 as a marketing campaign for ____.
During World War II, the U.S. military created a secret unit of artists and sound engineers called the ____ to deceive the enemy.
The 1848 California Gold Rush started when gold was found at ____.
Before it was the White House, the presidential residence was called the ____.
The Boston Tea Party protesters disguised themselves as ____.
In 1919, a massive wave of ____ killed 21 people and destroyed buildings in Boston.
The Pony Express mail delivery service lasted only ____ before being replaced by the telegraph.
During the War of 1812, the British burned down every government building in Washington D.C. except the ____.
The original 13 colonies were founded between 1607 and 1733, with ____ being the last.
The Statue of Liberty's original color was ____ before it turned green from oxidation.
In 1958, the current 50-star American flag was designed by a ____ for a school project.
The Pentagon was built with twice as many bathrooms as necessary because of ____ segregation laws.
America's first capital city was not Washington D.C. — it was ____.
During the Dust Bowl, massive dust storms were so dark that people called them ____.
The Erie Canal, completed in 1825, connected the Great Lakes to the ____.
alternateAnswers: Atlantic Ocean via the Hudson River

question: Harriet Tubman not only led slaves to freedom, she also served as a ____ for the Union Army during the Civil War.
The last state to join the Union was ____ in 1959.
In 1835, the U.S. national debt was briefly reduced to ____ — the only time in history.
The Transcontinental Railroad was completed in 1869 when the two lines met at ____, Utah.
Before the American Revolution, colonists protested British taxes by refusing to buy ____.
During World War II, Americans collected ____ from their kitchens to help make explosives.
The Great Chicago Fire of 1871 burned for ____ straight days.
Salem's famous witch trials of 1692 resulted in the execution of ____ people.
The Alamo, the famous 1836 battle site, was originally built as a ____.
In 1804, the Lewis and Clark expedition brought a ____ as a key member who helped them survive.
The first Thanksgiving in 1621 lasted ____ days.
The Declaration of Independence was actually signed by most delegates on ____, not July 4th.
In 1929, the stock market crash that started the Great Depression happened on a day nicknamed ____.
The underground railroad was neither underground nor a railroad — it was a network of ____.
During the Revolutionary War, George Washington famously crossed the ____ River on Christmas night 1776.
The first woman to run for President of the United States was ____ in 1872.
Route 66, the famous highway from Chicago to Los Angeles, was nicknamed the ____.
In 1947, a pilot named Kenneth Arnold saw objects in the sky and described them as ____, coining a famous term.
The Emancipation Proclamation of 1863 only freed slaves in ____.
Before the Star-Spangled Banner, America's unofficial national anthem was ____.
In 1961, the Freedom Riders were civil rights activists who rode ____ through the segregated South.
The Louisiana Purchase in 1803 doubled the size of the U.S. and cost about ____ per acre.
America's bloodiest single day of combat was the Battle of ____ during the Civil War.
The 19th Amendment, giving women the right to vote, wasn't ratified until ____.
During the Cold War, American schoolchildren practiced ____ drills in case of nuclear attack.
In 1803, the duel between Alexander Hamilton and Aaron Burr took place in ____.
The American flag's nickname "Old Glory" was given by a ____ captain named William Driver.
In 1773, the amount of tea dumped in the Boston Tea Party was worth approximately ____ in today's money.
Before becoming president, Abraham Lincoln was a licensed ____.
President William Howard Taft once got stuck in the ____ at the White House.
John Quincy Adams reportedly kept a pet ____ in the White House.
Calvin Coolidge's nickname was "____" because he rarely spoke.
Theodore Roosevelt was shot in the chest before a speech and still ____.
James Buchanan is the only president who never ____.
Before becoming president, Ulysses S. Grant was working as a ____ and was essentially broke.
President Andrew Jackson's pet parrot had to be removed from his funeral because it wouldn't stop ____.
George Washington's famous teeth were not made of wood — they were actually made of ____.
Jimmy Carter was the first president born in a ____.
President Lyndon B. Johnson owned an amphibious car and loved scaring guests by driving it into a ____.
William Henry Harrison gave the longest inaugural address in history and died ____ days later.
Barack Obama's favorite TV show was reportedly ____.
Richard Nixon was an accomplished ____ and once performed at the Grand Ole Opry.
Thomas Jefferson and John Adams both died on the same day: ____.
Harry Truman's middle initial "S" didn't actually stand for ____.
President James Garfield could simultaneously write in ____ with one hand and Greek with the other.
Gerald Ford was the only president who was never ____ as either president or vice president.
Grover Cleveland is the only president to serve ____ non-consecutive terms.
Before becoming president, Ronald Reagan was president of the ____.
President Herbert Hoover and his wife spoke ____ in the White House to prevent staff from eavesdropping.
George H.W. Bush celebrated his 90th birthday by ____.
President Dwight Eisenhower was an amazing ____ and painted over 250 works.
Abraham Lincoln is enshrined in the ____ Hall of Fame.
John Tyler, the 10th president born in 1790, still has living ____ as of 2024.
Woodrow Wilson is the only president who held a ____ degree.
President Franklin Pierce was arrested while in office for running over a woman with his ____.
James Madison, the shortest president, stood only ____ tall.
President Chester Arthur was accused of being born in ____ and not being a natural-born citizen.
Teddy Roosevelt's famous stuffed ____ toy was named after him.
Bill Clinton's favorite fast food restaurant was ____.
President Martin Van Buren was the first president born as a citizen of ____ rather than a British subject.
Zachary Taylor died after eating too many ____ at a Fourth of July celebration.
JFK was the first president to hold a press conference on ____.
Benjamin Harrison was the first president to have ____ in the White House, but he was afraid to touch the switches.
George Washington's annual salary as president was ____ of the total U.S. budget.
Warren G. Harding once lost the White House ____ set in a poker game.
President Millard Fillmore reportedly installed the first ____ in the White House.
Andrew Johnson never attended a single day of ____ in his life.
Franklin Roosevelt served an unprecedented ____ terms as president.
President James Polk promised to serve only one term and accomplished every ____ he set during his campaign.
John F. Kennedy donated his entire presidential ____ to charity.
President Rutherford B. Hayes hosted the first ____ hunt at the White House.
Dwight Eisenhower was so popular that ____ political parties tried to recruit him to run for president.
Richard Nixon's last words were reportedly asking for ____.
Theodore Roosevelt was blind in one ____ from a boxing match while president.
President Obama was known for always wearing only ____ or blue suits to reduce decision fatigue.
Abraham Lincoln kept important documents stored in his ____.
George Washington's favorite food was reportedly ____.
John Adams was the first president to live in the ____.
Before entering politics, Donald Trump made a cameo appearance in the movie ____.
alternateAnswers: Home Alone 2: Lost in New York

question: Trump's childhood dream job was to be a ____.
Donald Trump received a ____ deferment from the Vietnam War draft.
Trump Tower in Manhattan has ____ floors, though Trump claims it has more.
In the 1990s, Trump owned the ____ beauty pageant organization.
Trump's first wife, Ivana, was a competitive ____ from Czechoslovakia.
Donald Trump's star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame was given for his work in ____.
Trump's book "The Art of the Deal" was co-written by ghostwriter ____.
Before becoming president, Trump made a memorable appearance at WrestleMania where he ____ Vince McMahon's head.
Trump served McDonald's hamburgers as dinner at the White House to celebrate the ____ football team.
Donald Trump's favorite food at McDonald's is reportedly the ____.
Trump played himself in the 2011 comedy series "____" on Comedy Central.
Trump's Mar-a-Lago estate in Florida was originally built by cereal heiress ____.
During the 2016 campaign, Trump famously descended a golden ____ to announce his candidacy.
Trump was the first president to communicate major policy decisions via ____.
In the 1990s, Trump owned a professional ____ league called the New Jersey Generals.
Trump's Secret Service code name was ____.
Before politics, Trump had his own branded ____ that sold at The Sharper Image.
Trump attended the ____ military academy as a teenager in New York.
Donald Trump's father, Fred, made his fortune building ____ in Brooklyn and Queens.
Trump once owned the iconic ____ Hotel and Casino in Atlantic City.
In 2006, Trump started ____ University, which later faced fraud lawsuits.
Trump's catchphrase on The Apprentice was "You're ____!"
During his presidency, Trump served ____ flavors of ice cream while guests got one.
Trump was the first president to meet a sitting leader of North Korea at the ____ border.
Melania Trump is originally from ____.
Trump reportedly drinks ____ cans of Diet Coke per day.
During his 2016 campaign, Trump threw rolls of ____ to hurricane survivors in Puerto Rico.
Trump Tower was built using concrete instead of steel partly because Trump had connections to the ____ industry.
Donald Trump's net worth dropped by about ____ during his first presidency, making him one of few presidents to lose money in office.
Trump made a brief cameo on the TV show "____" playing himself.
Before The Apprentice, Trump hosted ____ on NBC with beauty pageant contestants.
Trump's childhood home in Jamaica Estates, Queens was listed on Airbnb for ____ per night.
During his presidency, Trump installed a ____ simulator in the White House.
Trump has appeared on the cover of ____ magazine more times than any other person at the time.
In 1989, Trump bought an airline called ____ Shuttle.
Trump's 2017 inauguration crowd size became a major controversy when his press secretary called it the ____ ever.
At his rallies, Trump's signature walkout song is "____" by the Village People.
Trump reportedly asked about buying the country of ____ from Denmark.
Before running for president in 2016, Trump previously explored running in the year ____ under the Reform Party.
Trump once owned the General Motors Building in Manhattan, which he renamed the ____.
During COVID-19, Trump suggested that injecting ____ might treat the virus, causing widespread controversy.
Trump's youngest son, Barron, is notably tall — standing over ____ feet at age 18.
In 2020, Trump became the first sitting president to visit the ____ in Jerusalem.
Trump branded his own line of ____ called "Success" and "Empire."
Trump's first major real estate project was converting the old Commodore Hotel into the Grand ____.
When asked about his hair, Trump has said it takes him about ____ to style it each morning.
Trump was impeached ____ times during his first term as president.
In 2019, Trump served as grand marshal of the ____ 500 auto race.
Trump holds a degree in ____ from the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania.
